Award.AwardTitle: The Interactions of Biology, Chemistry and Physics at the Land-Ocean Interface: A Systemic PARTnership Aimed at Connecting University and School (SPARTACUS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract, GK-12 0841361 (U. of New England, Zeeman)

Technical Description. A Systemic PARTnership Aimed at Connecting University and School (SPARTACUS) project forms linkages among university researchers and their graduate students with the K-12 community. Focusing on the hydrologic cycle in a coastal watershed it conveys the importance of interdisciplinary efforts in scientific and social issues, to K-12 students and teachers through the work of Graduate Fellows and their advisors. Interrelationships of physics, chemistry, biology, mathematics, and geology are examined in a local watershed using the Saco River Coastal Observing System (SaRCOS). It investigates how precipitation drives river discharge, which in turn, governs the coastal current, which influences coastal weather. While scientifically important, these phenomena are also tangible to students at all levels.
Broader Impacts. The project engages K-12 students and teachers in authentic inquiry-based learning in STEM-related disciplines. This unique project brings together school districts? needs, scientific research, and place-based inquiry education. Graduate Fellows gain an understanding of the educational process, develop communication skills and team building, and appreciate the importance of K-12 outreach as a professional commitment. Place-based inquiry projects are used to engage students in active learning. Schools benefit from professional development of teachers, and enrichment of the learning environment, while society gains greater scientific and technical literacy. The schools encompass rural to urban settings, including the two largest and most ethnically diverse districts in Maine. Replication of the model is highly viable since it is grounded in local environs and research, effectively connecting the community, school and university.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Interactions of Biology, Chemistry and Physics at the Land-Ocean Interface: A Systemic PARTnership Aimed at Connecting University and School (SPARTACUS) built meaningful connections between university researchers, their graduate students and the K-12 community. The project focused on the Saco River watershed imparting knowledge about its ecosystem to the researchers, K-12 students and inhabitants of the Saco region and the Gulf of Maine watershed. 

The project extended its impact in three directions The University reached out to schools to meet the needs identified by school districts in their K-12 science curriculum. The schools opened their classrooms to be transformed, allowing students to become scientists on their own campuses and in their own communities. The graduate students (hereafter called Fellows) built the bridges to share with students the excitement of conducting field research in hopes they too might pursue a science career while learning how to communicate complex science content to widely varying audiences.

Impact to K-12 Students

As a measure of impact on the schools, twenty-one Fellows completed the SPARTACUS program over the six years of the project. Twenty-two teachers from seven school districts shared their classrooms with the Fellows. Each Fellow spent ten hours a week in classrooms over forty weeks per year. Over the course of SPARTACUS more than 4500 students in grades 3-12 each received more than 80 hours of enriched science instruction per year. As well, more than 350 at risk students in grades 2-5 from the towns of Portland and Biddeford each received more than eight hours of after school enrichment per year. Together, the SPARTACUS project supported over 20,000 hours of science enrichment to students in the region enlivening their interest in science careers.

Impact to K-12 Teachers

Teachers collaborated on classroom instruction with Fellows for fifteen hours a week over the forty-week school year. As well, teachers attended a one-hour seminar every other week during the school year and a one-week Summer Institute each summer. Many remarked that having a scientist in the classroom was the best professional development they had received. Each year this would total 660 hours of professional development a year, assuring a deeper understanding of science content and practices to inform their instruction.

Impact to the University

Each graduate student in the University of New England master’s program must present their findings to a professional organization and prepare a manuscript for publication in a peer-reviewed journal. Over the six years of the project, the Fellows and Principal Investigators produced nearly 100 papers and presentations on the Fellows’ research. These theses and publications are available through the UNE library. Once data are published, theses are released in digital form for easy distribution to others in the field. Links to the students, their abstracts and/or theses are all posted on the University’s web site.

Dialogue has also increased across the UNE campus on the value of outreach to the K-12 education community. Conversations at all levels of the administration have encouraged professors and their graduate students to follow the roles modeled in the SPARTACUS project, sharing their research and expertise with teachers and students in the region.

Broader Impact

The strongest impact of this program to society will be felt in the Saco River watershed, the fifth largest river in Maine and largest in South...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The Interactions of Biology, Chemistry and Physics at the Land-Ocean Interface: A Systemic PARTnership Aimed at Connecting University and School (SPARTACUS) built meaningful connections between university researchers, their graduate students and the K-12 community. The project focused on the Saco River watershed imparting knowledge about its ecosystem to the researchers, K-12 students and inhabitants of the Saco region and the Gulf of Maine watershed. The project extended its impact in three directions The University reached out to schools to meet the needs identified by school districts in their K-12 science curriculum. The schools opened their classrooms to be transformed, allowing students to become scientists on their own campuses and in their own communities. The graduate students (hereafter called Fellows) built the bridges to share with students the excitement of conducting field research in hopes they too might pursue a science career while learning how to communicate complex science content to widely varying audiences. Impact to K-12 Students As a measure of impact on the schools, twenty-one Fellows completed the SPARTACUS program over the six years of the project. Twenty-two teachers from seven school districts shared their classrooms with the Fellows. Each Fellow spent ten hours a week in classrooms over forty weeks per year. Over the course of SPARTACUS more than 4500 students in grades 3-12 each received more than 80 hours of enriched science instruction per year. As well, more than 350 at risk students in grades 2-5 from the towns of Portland and Biddeford each received more than eight hours of after school enrichment per year. Together, the SPARTACUS project supported over 20,000 hours of science enrichment to students in the region enlivening their interest in science careers. Impact to K-12 Teachers Teachers collaborated on classroom instruction with Fellows for fifteen hours a week over the forty-week school year. As well, teachers attended a one-hour seminar every other week during the school year and a one-week Summer Institute each summer. Many remarked that having a scientist in the classroom was the best professional development they had received. Each year this would total 660 hours of professional development a year, assuring a deeper understanding of science content and practices to inform their instruction. Impact to the University Each graduate student in the University of New England masterÆs program must present their findings to a professional organization and prepare a manuscript for publication in a peer-reviewed journal. Over the six years of the project, the Fellows and Principal Investigators produced nearly 100 papers and presentations on the FellowsÆ research. These theses and publications are available through the UNE library. Once data are published, theses are released in digital form for easy distribution to others in the field. Links to the students, their abstracts and/or theses are all posted on the UniversityÆs web site. Dialogue has also increased across the UNE campus on the value of outreach to the K-12 education community. Conversations at all levels of the administration have encouraged professors and their graduate students to follow the roles modeled in the SPARTACUS project, sharing their research and expertise with teachers and students in the region. Broader Impact The strongest impact of this program to society will be felt in the Saco River watershed, the fifth largest river in Maine and largest in Southern Maine. The research conducted by Fellows increased understanding of the watershed and its estuary and provided needed information that will be available for community decision-makers. Some of the important outcomes from research conducted through SPARTACUS will help improve management of the ecosystem. Numerous studies conducted by the Fellows also will affect those dependent upon Gulf of Maine fisheries both economically and as consumers. These studies ...
